subject: Re: [junit] Paramter/Data test files?
msgSnippet: ... It doesn t to me. There is a certain category of tests where the code that implements the test doesn t change :  it s the data that you feed it that needs
messageBody:
On 06 Apr 2007 07:48:06 -0700, Darren S. Eyers <dseyers@...> wrote:

> Spoke to a friend who said you should not have properties in a properties
> file as gives dependence on files for test cases (makes good sense).

It doesn't to me.

There is a certain category of tests where the code that implements
the test doesn't change : it's the data that you feed it that needs
to change. Such tests are called data-driven tests, and it makes a
lot of sense to externalize the data in such cases.

> Now I need to test some MS Excel files (program uses Java POI) so I think
> now really I need to refer to file as a bit big to put into a String in the
> test case!

Indeed, a lot of data-driven tests that I have seen are driven by
Excel spreadsheets, so your scenario is pretty common.

> Are there any classes (out of the box I am not aware of) for reading
> properties files in the current test case and other files like Excel?
> Curios on the previous, but will keep with constants in the test case.

Both JUnit 4 and TestNG support data-driven test. Do a search for
these keywords in the relevant documentation or feel free to ask more
specific questions.

--
Cédric
